map.thesis: To address the governance gap in post-urbanization fragile territories under the EU 2028-2034 R&I mandate, the European Union must institutionalize Applied Research Organizations (AROs) operating in Pasteur's Quadrant as a distinct structural layer of territorial governance.

claims.claim: Current EU territorial governance mechanisms exhibit a 'structural lag,' failing to address the specific wicked problems of fragile, post-urbanized landscapes where standard market-driven or purely academic interventions are ineffective.
evidence_needed: Demographic and economic data showing the divergence between urban centers and fragile territories despite existing Cohesion Policy
Policy analysis of current Smart Specialization Strategies (S3) identifying gaps in rural/peripheral application
Literature review on 'places that left behind' and the failure of sector-blind policies
counter_arguments: Existing Cohesion Policy and CAP (Common Agricultural Policy) instruments are sufficient if better implemented
Digitalization and remote work trends will naturally correct territorial imbalances without new institutions

claims.claim: The 'Pasteur's Quadrant' model (use-inspired basic research) provides the necessary epistemological framework for AROs to bridge the gap between high-level EU policy goals and hyper-local implementation, a function traditional universities and consultancies cannot fulfill.
evidence_needed: Comparative analysis of incentive structures in Universities (publication-driven) vs. Commercial R&D (profit-driven) vs. AROs (mission-driven)
Theoretical mapping of territorial fragility problems against the Pasteur’s Quadrant framework
Epistemological critique of current 'projectification' of research in rural contexts
counter_arguments: Universities are already shifting to 'Third Mission' activities and can fill this role
Creating a new class of organizations adds unnecessary bureaucratic complexity to the R&I landscape

claims.claim: The emerging strategic orientation of the EU 2028-2034 R&I mandate (FP10 context) creates a specific political and financial window for mission-oriented intermediaries that prioritize societal resilience and place-based innovation.
evidence_needed: Textual analysis of High-Level Group reports and working documents regarding FP10/post-Horizon Europe
Review of the 'Mission-Oriented Innovation Policy' (MOIP) evolution within EU structures
Budgetary trend analysis favoring impact-driven ecosystems over isolated excellence
counter_arguments: The 2028-2034 mandate will prioritize defense, industrial competitiveness, and AI over territorial cohesion
Place-based policies are being deprioritized in favor of sector-based industrial strategies

claims.claim: Emergent 'proto-AROs' and experimental living labs currently operating in fragile European territories provide validatable prototypes of the ARO model, demonstrating that local embedding is a prerequisite for successful technological and social transfer.
evidence_needed: Case studies of existing independent research institutes or Living Labs in peripheral EU regions
Impact metrics comparing 'fly-in/fly-out' research interventions vs. embedded institutional presence
Interviews with regional stakeholders regarding trust and adoption of innovation
counter_arguments: Current success stories are anecdotal and dependent on charismatic leadership rather than replicable models
These organizations lack financial sustainability without perpetual public subsidy

claims.claim: To scale successfully, AROs must be structured not as isolated projects but as a networked institutional infrastructure that balances local autonomy with EU-wide knowledge exchange.
evidence_needed: Organizational design models for federalized or networked research institutes (e.g., Fraunhofer model adapted for fragility)
Governance framework proposals for EU-Local partnerships
Analysis of funding mechanisms that allow for long-term operational stability vs. short-term project cycles
counter_arguments: A standardized institutional model cannot account for the extreme heterogeneity of European territories
Centralized EU networking requirements will stifle the local agility that makes AROs effective
